cells.data:
Chapter 2: Sets

A set $A$ is a an unordered collection of objects called elements or members
$A$ contains its elements; that is, $a \in A$

$A,B$ are equal if they have the same elements; that is, $A = B \iff \forall x : (x \in A) \iff (x \in B)$

Some sets:
$\mathbb{N} = \{ 0, 1, 2, 3, \dots \}$
$\mathbb{Z} = \{ -\mathbb{N}\setminus 0, \mathbb{N} \}$
$\mathbb{Q} = $ set of rational numbers
$\mathbb{R} = $ set of reals
$\mathbb{C} = $ set of complex numbers

Set builder notation (as opposed to listing out elements)
$A = \{ x : P(x) \}$

Empty set
$\emptyset = \varnothing = \{\}$
$\emptyset \subseteq $ any set (vacuously)

We also have $x \notin A$

Subsets
$A \subseteq B \iff \forall x (x \in A) \implies (x \in B)$
$A \subset B \iff (\forall x (x \in A) \implies (x \in B)) \land (\exists y (y \in B \land y \notin A))$

Finally, intersection and union
$A \cap B = \{ x : (x \in A \land x \in B) \}$
$A \cup B = \{ x : (x \in A \lor x \in B) \}$

A set with only finitely many elements is called a finite set (as opposed to an infinite set)
$|A|$ is the cardinality of $A$; that is, the number of elements it contains

Power set
$P(S) = \{ A : A \subseteq S \}$ for $A$ is a set

E.g.,
$S = \{ 1, 2 \}$
$P(S) = \{ \emptyset, \{1\}, \{2\}, \{1,2\} \}$

Russel's paradox (message: be careful building sets)
Let $S$ be all the set of all sets that do not contain themselves as an element
Then $S = \{ x : x \notin x \}$ for $x$ is a set
Is $S \in S$?
(1) Assume $S \in S$; then $S$ must not be in $S$ and we reach a contradiction
(2) Assume $S \notin S$; then $S$ must be in $S$ and we reach a contradiction

Products
Suppose $A,B$ are sets. Then $A \times B = \{ (a,b) : a \in A, b \in B \}$
$|A \times B| = |A||B|$
$A_1 \times \dots \times A_n = \{ (a_1, \dots , a_n) : a_1 \in A_1, \dots, a_n \in A_n \}$

Ordered Pair: $(a,b)$
$(a_1,b_1) = (a_2,b_2) \iff a_1 = a_2 \land b_1 = b_2$
This extends to ordered $n$-tuples

Counting
$|P(S)| = 2^{|S|}$ (because we have two decisions for each element)
